Response
To open a dispensary, you must first confirm that cannabis is legal in your state and locality and then navigate a complex process of licensing, planning, and securing significant funding

. Because cannabis is still illegal at the federal level, securing loans and complying with regulations is more challenging than with other businesses.

Before you apply

Research state and local laws. Cannabis regulations differ greatly by state and even by municipality. You must understand all the relevant laws, including whether you are permitted to sell medical, recreational, or both types of cannabis.

Form a legal business entity. Register your business with your state's Secretary of State. This is a required first step before you can apply for a license.

Create a detailed business plan. This is a critical document required by most licensing bodies. It should outline your business goals, operational strategy, market analysis, compliance plan, security measures, and financial projections.

Secure significant funding. Dispensaries require substantial startup capital, often between $250,000 and $2 million, depending on your location and the size of your operation.

Because of federal laws, traditional bank loans are difficult to obtain.
Alternative funding sources include private equity, angel investors, specialized cannabis lenders, crowdfunding, or personal assets.
Choose a compliant location. You must find a retail property that complies with all state and local zoning laws, including restrictions on proximity to schools or residential areas. Working with a cannabis real estate agent can help navigate these limitations.

Develop a security plan. Licensing authorities require a robust security plan that typically includes surveillance systems, vaults for product storage, and strict access control to meet compliance standards.

The application and licensing process

Submit state license application. Apply for a cannabis retail license through your state's cannabis regulatory agency. The application requires extensive documentation, including your business plan, proof of capital, details on your management team, and a security plan.
Obtain local approval. After receiving state approval, you must get approval from the city or county where your dispensary is located. Local governments have their own permitting requirements and zoning rules.
Pay fees. Be prepared to pay licensing fees. For example, in Ohio, fees can include a $5,000 application fee and a $70,000 initial certificate of operation fee.
Pass background checks. All owners and key personnel will undergo comprehensive background checks, including fingerprinting, as part of the licensing process.
After licensing

Build out your store. Once approved, you can design and build your dispensary interior, ensuring the layout and security features match your plans.
Source inventory. Establish relationships with licensed cultivators and distributors to stock your shelves with compliant products.
Hire and train staff. Hire budtenders and other employees and ensure they are properly trained on products, state regulations, and customer service.
Implement technology. Select a compliant point-of-sale (POS) system and other software to manage inventory, sales, and track all compliance data for state reporting.
Develop a marketing strategy. Research and implement your marketing plan to attract customers while following strict advertising guidelines for cannabis businesses.
